content: This contribution hasn’t received enough positive votes from the community. The "FASTEST" option has therefore been deactivated.
This contribution hasn’t received enough positive votes from the community. The "REVERSE" option has therefore been deactivated.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I really like the fact that people with some math knowledge and a sheet can achieve to solve this pretty fast.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Some physics is good for health

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice speed bump. Props to you on one of my favorite clash contributions i've seen reccently. Very simple, good thought problem.
The puzzle is solvable without knowing the formula for the sum of infinite series. Of course the coding will take more time and in shortest mode using the formula would be advantageous.
I'm not sure it could be solved in reverse mode. One typo Iˇve spotted is: evey in the goal section.

I would presume that everyone remembers about the sum of an infinite series (even if they don't remember the actual equation). The extra tweak to the series makes it interesting.

There are quite a few typos here and there (if you need help finding them, feel free to ask), but otherwise I like this CoC.
Hi UnicornP, thank you for offering to help with correcting "typos". I have currently only limited access to computer, but will include your corrections asap!
Hello seitec01, I was worried about the reverse - the problem being too simple so that the problem statement is some kind of camouflage :) I tought that the multiplication with 9 is too transparent.

Here are my suggestions:

Statement:
When a rubber ball is dropped, it bounces several times before coming to rest as it loses energy. It loses one-fifth of its total energy with every bounce. As potential energy is directly proportional to height, this means that the highest point after every bounce is 80% as high as the previous one. Calculate the total distance that the ball travels.

Input:
<<Line 1:>> An integer [[N]] representing the number of cases
<<Next [[N]] lines:>> The initial height [[H]] of the ball for each case (unit-less)

Output:
<<[[N]] lines:>> An integer representing the total distance traveled for each case

Constraints:
1 ≤ [[N]] ≤ 100
0 ≤ [[H]] ≤ 100
Thank you UnicornP, you rewrote my problem description and I must admit that your wording was a lot better than mine. So I shamelessly copied it. Hope you do not mind.
